awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Form and Function in Cortical Neuronal Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The cerebral cortex is the central processing area of the brain.  Nearly all higher cognitive functions depend on the activity patterns of cortical neuron populations.  These activity patterns are shaped by the structure of connectivity between cortical neurons and, conversely, cortical connectivity is shaped by cortical activity through changes in connection strengths called "synaptic plasticity."  This project will develop novel computational models and mathematical analyses to understand the interplay between cortical connectivity and cortical activity, and how it gives rise to cognitive functions like sensory processing and motor learning.  The results will lead to a better understanding of how the cortex functions and how it dysfunctions in disease states.  The results will also inform the development of biologically-inspired machine learning algorithms.  Graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in all aspects of the research and benefit from coursework inspired by the research projects.  Students at a public high school will be guided in a project to incorporate learning algorithms from the research into a robot, providing hands on experience with applied mathematics, computer programming, and robotics.

The project comprises three sub-projects that build on each other.  The first sub-project utilizes the notion of excitatory-inhibitory balance in cortical networks to derive scaling laws for connection strengths at large network size.  Previous theoretical work elucidates the computational utility of an inverse square root scaling law and recent experimental work provides biological evidence for it, but the mechanisms through which the law could emerge are unknown.  Candidate biological mechanisms will be analyzed mathematically and evaluated in collaboration with an experimental neuroscientist.  For the second project, the theory of neuronal networks with excitatory and inhibitory balance will be refined and extended to account for the imprecision of balance observed in experiments.  Preliminary calculations suggest that this imprecision is mathematically necessary, produces biologically realistic activity, and invokes intricate response properties that have implications for artificial neural networks used for image analysis.  The third project will develop and analyze a mathematical model of motor learning that combines Hebbian plasticity in a cortical pathway with reward modulated plasticity in a sub-cortical pathway, inspired by experimental observations.  This two-pathway motor learning algorithm has implications for biological motor learning, motor disease, and robotics.

por.por_cntn:
The cerebral cortex is the central processing area of the brain. Nearly all higher cognitive functions depend on the activity patterns of cortical neuron populations. These activity patterns are shaped by the structure of connectivity between cortical neurons and, conversely, cortical connectivity is shaped by cortical activity through changes in connection strengths called "synaptic plasticity." The question of how learning and function emerge from this interplay between cortical activity and cortical connectivity is a major frontier of modern science. 


In this project, the PI, Robert Rosenbaum, worked with PhD students and external collaborators to combine computational modeling, mathematical analysis, and neural recordings to uncover fundamental insights into how learning and function emerge in cortical neural circuits.
Neural circuits in the cerebral cortex are densely interconnected. Some neurons send positively polarized, or "excitatory," electrical signals to their neighboring neurons while other neurons send negatively polarized or "inhibitory" signals. At the population level, the overall level of excitation and inhibition is tightly balanced. This push-and-pull balance between excitation and inhibition is widely observed in neural recordings and appears to be broken in some situations, including some disease states. A major component of this project was devoted to understanding how excitatory and inhibitory signals is maintained, how it is broken under some circumstances, and its role in learning. Supported PhD students used computational modeling and mathematical analysis to derive conditions that must be satisfied for balance to be maintained, and derived learning rules that operate in interconnected networks with excitatory-inhibitory balance. Results were compared with neural recordings and used to make novel, testable predictions. 


In addition, Rosenbaum worked on several educational and pedagogical activities. Rosenbaum volunteered with a local high school to work with the school's Robotics Club to incorporate some of the learning rules from the project into the students' robots. Rosenbaum also helped the high school students build robots for the FIRST Indiana Robotics competitions. Rosenbaum also mentored several undergraduate students in research projects that exposed the students to important topics in artificial intelligence, data analysis, computer programming, and mathematical modeling. Rosenbaum also developed and taught two new undergraduate courses in Computational Neuroscience and Artificial Neural Networks, in which topics from the supported research were incorporated as demonstrative examples. Finally, Rosenbaum wrote a new undergraduate textbook in Computational Neuroscience based on his course. The textbook is under contract for publication with MIT Press. The textbook is, and will remain, freely available as a PDF download. In addition, computer code to produce all examples in the textbook is maintained by Rosenbaum on a public webpage.
